bibl.title: Letter from Eduardo Angles to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 29, 1941

div1.p: Angles is satisfied with the handling of the Finlay question.

div1.head: Letter from Eduardo Angles to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 29, 1941
div1.opener:
DR. EDUARDO ANGLES
MEDICO CIRUJANO
-----
GENERAL LEE NO. 19.
TELEFONO FO-7163
MARIANAO
---
March 29, 1941
Dear Dr. Kean:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter dated
March 24th. I am glad to hear that you are well. Your
clear and strong handwriting denotes your well-being and
the good functioning of your brain. Regarding myself I'll
say I am pretty well although my legs are rather weak.

I'm sorry I caused you to worry over the
irregularities I mentioned about our Post-office service.
Of course it isn't your fault. In this country letters
very often get misplaced.

I received yours of January 29, 1941 and
answered on the 19th of February. I did not however re-
ceive yours dated Feb. 25th. I'm sorry not to have re-
ceived it because a letter from you is always very wel-
come but apart from that is is not important. Let's for-
get about it. It is neither your fault nor mine, and with
this, we settle the matter.

I have not seen Dr. Roldan lately but I
am very satisfied how the Finlay question is being
settled on the basis of cordiality, understanding, and
justice.

I certainly hope to hear from you when
Mrs. de Chadenedes pays you a visit. From her you will
know how very much I esteem you and yours.

I most assuredly will keep in touch with
you--hope you do the same.
div1.closer: Most sincerely yours, Dr. Ed. Angles Dr. Eduardo Angles
